content.description: A really fun problem. Move off scoops to right sidepull, then move left off slopers for the V5, moving up and right is V4.
content.location: Southwest corner of Tee Pee Boulder

content.description: Pull from underneath rail to slopey holds on arete, pull over arete and work your way up the delicate slab to highball top.
content.location: Starts under the south west corner arete on rounded rail.

content.description: Start on the left side (of the north face) with the right hand in an undercling and the left hand on a low side pull. Traverse right on crimps and another undercling to the good rail. From here, go up to the obvious slightly hollow side pull (crux around here). Top out.
content.location: On the north side of Ripple boulder. It's very obvious. As you approach the Tee Pee Boulder area, this is one of the first problems you see. Chalky holds on a varnished face.

content.description: Continuation of Ripploid that finishes on Mantel Man. Long crimp traverse.
Start low with matched under-clings on a huge jug, move left to a pocket, and then to the lip. Pull the lip and head for the top.
content.location: Just right of Underwhere, on the Ripple Boulder.

content.description: Start on obvious crimp >> undercling >> scary mantle >> top out.
content.protection: Highball, bring a mondo and a buddy.
content.location:
Mantle Man

is on the NW corner of the

Tee Pee Boulder

and has an obvious mantle in the middle of the route.

content.description:
Hard moves right off the ground to an amazing cross move and potential heartbreaking top-out.

Start with left hand in a hole created by what looks like a intrusion make by petrified wood and right hand crimp and shoot up right to a good in-cut crimp.  Some fine-tuned beta here can make this reasonable.  From here work your way left using drop knees, heel hooks, toe hooks and everything in between to cross into the diagonal crimp.  This hold has broken fairly recently, potentially making this (the crux move) harder (easier??).  From here make your way out to crimps on the face and a juggy top out avoiding the horizontal swing.
content.location: Located on the opposite corner of Underwhere.

content.description: From east-face traverse left on low pockets around corner and up face
content.location: Starts on the east side of the ripple boulder and moves to the south side, just right of the crack

content.description: Bizarre climbing that looks like it's going to be fun, but mostly is not. Start sitting, and work your way up the holds left of the arete, using the arete as you like.
content.location: Just left of Lindner's Roof on the Ripple Boulder, faces the washout/dry streambed.

content.description: Awkward sit start on the lowest of chalked holds (slopy edges) and a left heel hook to start may prove to be easier. Continue straight up on the obvious holds.
content.location: To the left of Jack's Arete

content.description: Lay start on jugs to sloping crimps that are constantly getting worse. Big hard bump then awkward holds to top out. Route used to be v6 but crimps are getting very slopey.
content.location: Just left of jibber in south side.

content.description: Start on the lowest chalked holds below Mantle Man. Work up along some crimps and slopey arete to the undercling on Mantle Man and finish as per that problem.
content.location: On the Ripploid boulder, the first large boulder you see when you hike into the main area of Moes
